SELL SEASON TICKETS!
Every year when football season is over and the sporting
pages of Baltimore newspapers become filled with long accounts
of soccer, which is already under way, and basketball, which is
about to start, a few enthusiasts on the campus and many complainers set up a cry for these sports.
The enthusiasts really make an effort to start teams. Every
year someone makes plans that die chiefly from lack of financial
support. The complainers then take the field and lament the small'
college tendencies of John Hopkins. They bewail the fact that
the football team is weak, that we really have only two sports
on the campus, and, that only one of these has ever done anything actually to increase the fame of the University.
There is an old saw that criticism is valueless if it is not
constructive. There is an equally old answer that 99% of the
criticism one comes into contact with tears down but is completely
void of helpfulness. The reason these self-appointed critics do
more harm than good is that they do not investigate actual conditions; they do not try to find the causes for things which appear
to them as pure deficiency on the part of the athletic officials;
they content themselves with superficial observations arid at the
slightest invitation vent themselves in the wisdom that comes
from knowing little of the actual facts.
In spite of this evident dissatisfaction the condition remains
the same. Each freshman class discovers it and every year the
same old story is dragged from the closet as though it were new.
It is a wonder the fact has not saturated the college to such an
extent that all concerned realize that the only way to improve
the situation is to obtain money.
The Athletic Association began this year $7,200 behind. The
dissenters talk of expanding the athletic program and the officials
would gladly do it. But the state of the treasury is so poor that
the Fifth Regiment.Games had to be done away with chiefly because of the inability to meet expenses.
In one more week the Athletic Association will launch the
1927 Ticket Campaign. That the association needs money has,
we think, been sufficiently shown. A rainy season for lacrosse
would do considerable damage to sports in general. The sale of
900 season tickets would enable the management of track and
lacrosse to put these teams on the proper basis and would insure
them against a rainy season.
- Five dollars provides any alumnus with a ticket to a lacrosse
game every Saturday from April 2 to May 21. The team plays
one game away but on that day L'Hirondelle and Philadelphia
play at Homewood and the season ticket will admit the bearer.
This is the most alluring offer ever made in a campaign of this
sort and the association is notifying the alumni of it in a series
of letters. The teams must have more money.
Athletics belong to the undergraduates. Students make up the
teams and furnish the bulk of attendance at games. Without
candidates the team cannot continue, without funds they cannot
play. The teams belong to the students and they must have
money. The spring season campaign is the only means they have
of gaining the necessary support.
R. R. G.

However, we feel that Mr. McKee's actions were prompted by his
kindness of heart.
In connection with that poor, poor
play, "The Virgin Man," about
which George Jean Nathan wrote
only three words—So Am /—was
this especially noticeable.
This play had been floundering
about barely able to induce a handful of people to attend each performance, and the producer had just
about decided to remove it, when
along comes "Big Hearted Joey"
and has everybody connected with
the play arrested and demands that
it be suppresed on the grounds of
its being immoral. The following
morning, of course, every tabloid in
the East had the title of this complete failure printed in large type
across the front page.
Injunctions were soon obtained
and the play has continued. And
the result of Mr. McKee's efforts
has been that "The Virgin Man"
has been playing before capacity
houses every evening and matinee
since that memorable afternoon
when Mr. McKee took his first sten
towards cleansing New York.

to us to be a sort of a nightmare.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 1, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
A Society for the Suppressidn of
Vice has been organized and recently held its first meeting and
election of officers at McGill University. Recommendations were
drawn up to be sent to the Student Council that all future dances
at the University should be canceled, since these earnest right
thinkers have resolved,"that modern dancing is lewd, lascivous, indecent, and obscene; and that, in
consequence, all dances and all
places where dancing is practiced
or exhibited before the public
should be ruthlessly wiped out."
The despicable habit of cigarette
smoking, beer guzzling, and indiscriminate handholding during lectures were also dissected and
heartily condemned by these earnest young men. What is this
Younger generatiOn coming to?

BLIND LECTURER TELLS
HIS LIFE STORY IN
ASSEMBLY TALK
Mr. N. C. Hanks, Although Sightless, Is
a College Graduate; and Expert
in Political icience

"No effort is without its compensation. No suffering is without
its just returns of happiness," said
Mr. N. C. Hanks in his lecture at
the Thursday's assembly on "Diamonds in the Rough."
Mr. Hanks, a graduate of Leland
Stanford, is sightless and without
hands. He is, furthermore, a specialist in social ethics and international law. He has crossed the
United States twenty-seven times,
and has delivered five thousand lectures. Mr. Hanks spoke of the
event which changed his life completely. It was in 1903 during the
summer vacation, when he was
working at a silver mine in the
Rocky Mountains. A dynamite
blast exploded prematurely in his
hands. He was hurled into the air
and fell twenty feet away, a mangled wreck, his eyes and hands
gone. There was only one other
person in the camp, who, in order
to obtain help, had to leave Mr.
Hanks alone for hours. When he
returned, bringing a doctor, he was
almost dead. "That was the last
day which I shall ever see."

SELL SEASON TICKETS!
Every year when football season is over and the sporting
pages of Baltimore newspapers become filled with long accounts
of soccer, which is already under way, and basketball, which is
about to start, a few enthusiasts on the campus and many complainers set up a cry for these sports.
The enthusiasts really make an effort to start teams. Every
year someone makes plans that die chiefly from lack of financial
support. The complainers then take the field and lament the small'
college tendencies of John Hopkins. They bewail the fact that
the football team is weak, that we really have only two sports
on the campus, and, that only one of these has ever done anything actually to increase the fame of the University.
There is an old saw that criticism is valueless if it is not
constructive. There is an equally old answer that 99% of the
criticism one comes into contact with tears down but is completely
void of helpfulness. The reason these self-appointed critics do
more harm than good is that they do not investigate actual conditions; they do not try to find the causes for things which appear
to them as pure deficiency on the part of the athletic officials;
they content themselves with superficial observations arid at the
slightest invitation vent themselves in the wisdom that comes
from knowing little of the actual facts.
In spite of this evident dissatisfaction the condition remains
the same. Each freshman class discovers it and every year the
same old story is dragged from the closet as though it were new.
It is a wonder the fact has not saturated the college to such an
extent that all concerned realize that the only way to improve
the situation is to obtain money.
The Athletic Association began this year $7,200 behind. The
dissenters talk of expanding the athletic program and the officials
would gladly do it. But the state of the treasury is so poor that
the Fifth Regiment.Games had to be done away with chiefly because of the inability to meet expenses.
In one more week the Athletic Association will launch the
1927 Ticket Campaign. That the association needs money has,
we think, been sufficiently shown. A rainy season for lacrosse
would do considerable damage to sports in general. The sale of
900 season tickets would enable the management of track and
lacrosse to put these teams on the proper basis and would insure
them against a rainy season.
- Five dollars provides any alumnus with a ticket to a lacrosse
game every Saturday from April 2 to May 21. The team plays
one game away but on that day L'Hirondelle and Philadelphia
play at Homewood and the season ticket will admit the bearer.
This is the most alluring offer ever made in a campaign of this
sort and the association is notifying the alumni of it in a series
of letters. The teams must have more money.
Athletics belong to the undergraduates. Students make up the
teams and furnish the bulk of attendance at games. Without
candidates the team cannot continue, without funds they cannot
play. The teams belong to the students and they must have
money. The spring season campaign is the only means they have
of gaining the necessary support.
R. R. G.

A Society for the Suppressidn of
Vice has been organized and recently held its first meeting and
election of officers at McGill University. Recommendations were
drawn up to be sent to the Student Council that all future dances
at the University should be canceled, since these earnest right
thinkers have resolved,"that modern dancing is lewd, lascivous, indecent, and obscene; and that, in
consequence, all dances and all
places where dancing is practiced
or exhibited before the public
should be ruthlessly wiped out."
The despicable habit of cigarette
smoking, beer guzzling, and indiscriminate handholding during lectures were also dissected and
heartily condemned by these earnest young men. What is this
Younger generatiOn coming to?

BLIND LECTURER TELLS
HIS LIFE STORY IN
ASSEMBLY TALK
Mr. N. C. Hanks, Although Sightless, Is
a College Graduate; and Expert
in Political icience

"No effort is without its compensation. No suffering is without
its just returns of happiness," said
Mr. N. C. Hanks in his lecture at
the Thursday's assembly on "Diamonds in the Rough."
Mr. Hanks, a graduate of Leland
Stanford, is sightless and without
hands. He is, furthermore, a specialist in social ethics and international law. He has crossed the
United States twenty-seven times,
and has delivered five thousand lectures. Mr. Hanks spoke of the
event which changed his life completely. It was in 1903 during the
summer vacation, when he was
working at a silver mine in the
Rocky Mountains. A dynamite
blast exploded prematurely in his
hands. He was hurled into the air
and fell twenty feet away, a mangled wreck, his eyes and hands
gone. There was only one other
person in the camp, who, in order
to obtain help, had to leave Mr.
Hanks alone for hours. When he
returned, bringing a doctor, he was
almost dead. "That was the last
day which I shall ever see."
